TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Medial over sandy or sandy-skeletal, mixed, acid Aquandic Cryaquepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Salonie silt loam -- under native grass  (All colors are for moist soil)
Oe--2 1/2 to 0 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 2/2) mat of grass roots and partially decomposed organic matter; thin strata of silt loam; very strongly to strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (2 to 4 inches thick)
C1--0 to 1 1/2 inches; light gray (10YR 7/1) silt loam volcanic ash; massive; firm in place, friable when disturbed; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (1 to 2 inches thick)
C2--1 1/2 to 4 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) silt loam volcanic ash; massive; firm in place, friable when disturbed; strongly to medium acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
2C1--4 to 7 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) loamy fine sand volcanic ash; single grained; loose; mottled with yellowish red around root channels; few roots; strongly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
2C2--7 to 10 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) fine sand volcanic ash; single grained; loose; mottled with yellowish red; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (3 to 4 inches thick)
3Ab--10 to 10 1/2 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 2/2) mucky silt loam; very friable; many roots; strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 1 inch thick)
3Cb--10 1/2 to 19 inches; dark gray (5Y 4/1) silt loam; massive in place, parting to very fine subangular blocky; friable; slightly sticky; common roots; very strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 15 inches thick)
4C--19 to 31 inches +; black (5Y 2/1) gravelly very coarse sand; very strongly to strongly acid.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska.  Saltery Cove Road, 1.2 miles south of junction with Chiniak Cape Road at Middle Bay.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of recent volcanic ash ranges from 9 to 24 inches.  Texture of the uppermost layers ranges from silt loam to loamy fine sand.  In places, a thin recent deposit of alluvial silt overlies the ash.  The buried layer of silty alluvium ranges in thickness from 4 to 15 inches, but is usually 6 to 10 inches thick.  It may contain thin sandy or fine gravelly seams.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Kalsin and Olds series in the same family.  Kalsin soils have buried alluvial layers greater than 15 inches thick.  Olds soils have buried O horizons and more than 18 percent clay in the upper control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Salonie soils are on higher portions of floodplains along actively cutting streams.  They are formed in volcanic ash overlying alluvium from metamorphic rock and dark colored ashy soils on adjacent uplands.  The climate is cool maritime.  Average annual precipitation ranges from 50 to 70 inches, and the average annual temperature is about 40 degrees F.  Temperatures below freezing are recorded on fewer than 40 days annually, and temperatures above 70 degrees F. are rare.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These include the Kizhuyak, Kodiak, and Sharatin series.  Kizhuyak soils consist of thick alluvial accumulations of volcanic ash.  Kodiak soils have, under the recent volcanic ash deposit, dark reddish brown A horizons formed in older volcanic ash over glacial till.  Sharatin soils are like the Kodiak soils except that the buried solum overlies glacial outwash gravel rather than glacial till.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained.  Altered drainage is present in some pedons due to stream incisement.  Moderate over very rapid permeability.  Runoff is slow to medium.  Some areas are subject to occasional flooding.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used principally as grazing land.  Native grasses are cut in places for hay and silage, and there are a few gardens and seeded hay fields.  The native vegetation is tall grass, dominated by bluejoint reedgrass, and associated plants such as fireweed.  In places, the soil supportsd stands of cottonwood and willows.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern Kodiak Island, Alaska, and adjacent islands.  The series is of moderate extent

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska, 1959.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The concept of the Salonie series is poorly defined.  More data is needed to define the central concept or the series should be inactivated (jpm, 4/87).
Source of the volcanic ash is the 1912 eruption of Mt. Novarupta and Mt.  Katmai on the Alaska Peninsula.
